response:
[start of motion plan]
The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
- Object Properties: The human neck consists of soft tissue (skin, muscle) over rigid skeletal structures; it has moderate stiffness and compliance. The mass involved in the manipulation is minimal, mostly soft tissue with low mass (approx. 1-2 kg effective manipulated mass). The friction coefficient between skin and the robot's gripper surface will be moderate, assumed around 0.5 due to skin's slight moisture and soft pads on the gripper enhancing grip.
- Environmental Factors: The person is seated and supports some neck mass; gravity and natural resistance from muscles apply. Muscle tone provides damping and spring resistance to applied forces. No rigid hinge rotations but compliant tissue deformation.
- The relevant object is the man's neck, primarily soft tissue with a small effective mass of about 1.5 kg, and with the robot's soft gripper or padding, static friction coefficient estimated at 0.5.
- The surface of interaction is skin and clothing (cap and shirt), slightly compliant with friction coefficient approx. 0.4-0.5 with the robot's gripper material.
- Contact Types: The robot maintains a gentle but firm grasp of the neck using soft pads, ensuring even distributed pressure to avoid discomfort yet maintaining contact to perform massage motions.
- Motion Type: The massage involves combined sliding and pressing motions: the robot will grasp the neck and apply cyclic motions including light squeezing (compressive force), gentle rotations (twisting), and sliding motions along the neck surface.
- Contact Considerations: Forces must be applied to maintain a stable grasp without slipping, primarily normal forces along grasp directions, and tangential forces for sliding motions. Multiple axes of force application and torque will be necessary to emulate massage strokes.
- Motion along axes: The robot will use a combination of linear and rotational motions along wrist x (right/left), y (forward/back), and z (up/down) axes: small amplitude linear sliding along z (up/down), linear pressure in -y (pushing into neck), and rotational torque about x and z axes to simulate kneading/twisting.
- Task duration: The massage to be thorough suggests at least 1-2 minutes of cyclic motion to deliver a professional massage feel.

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates: effective manipulated mass ~1.5 kg, friction coefficient ~0.5, nominal grasp area contact pressure minimal to avoid discomfort but enough to prevent slip, estimated normal grasp force in range ~15-30 N.
- Relevant equations: Force required to prevent slip F_grip > F_shear / mu, where F_shear is maximum applied shear force.
- Relevant assumptions: Soft tissue compliance reduces peak force needed; motions are low velocity, low acceleration.
- Computations: Assuming maximum tangential forces during sliding ~5 N, grasp force must exceed F_shear/mu = 5N/0.5 = 10 N minimum; using 15-30 N range allows for safety margin.
- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass 1.5 kg and static friction coefficient of 0.5 along the surface: sliding forces ~5 N, vertical normal forces ~15-20 N for pressure; small torques about wrist axes ~0.3-0.5 N-m for kneading motion.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis:  To provide gentle lateral massage motions (right to left) along the neck, the robot must exert positive and negative force at around ±3 N cyclically. For planning, assume average no net force but active small forces as needed, thus No constant force required.
Linear Y-axis:  To maintain contact and apply pressure pushing into the neck from front (robot end-effector faces forward), the robot must exert a negative force along Y-axis of approximately 15 N to sustain grasp and compressive massage pressure.
Linear Z-axis:  For sliding massage strokes moving upwards/downwards along the neck, the robot must exert a bidirectional linear force along Z-axis approximately ±5 N, averaging zero over the massage.
Angular X-axis: To simulate kneading/twisting, small clockwise and counterclockwise torques about the X-axis of roughly ±0.4 N-m are applied cyclically; no constant torque required.
Angular Y-axis: No significant rotation about wrist Y-axis expected; No motion required.
Angular Z-axis: To support rotational components of massage, bidirectional torque about Z-axis around ±0.3 N-m applied intermittently; no constant torque required.
Grasping force:  To avoid slipping and provide appropriate massage pressure on compliant soft tissue, grasp force estimated between 15 and 30 N, balancing comfort and stability.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "Human neck soft tissue, approx. 1.5 kg effective mass, moderate stiffness, friction coefficient ~0.5 with soft robot gripper pads."
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Combined linear sliding motions up/down (+/- Z), applied compressive force pushing in -Y, small lateral X cyclic forces, and twisting torques about X and Z axes to simulate kneading."
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [0.0, -15.0, 0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 0.0]  # steady forces for grasping and compression only; cyclic forces and torques added dynamically in real control
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 20.0
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 120.0
```

[end of motion plan]
message:
Given the user instruction and an image of the robot workspace, generate a structured physical plan for a robot end-effector interacting with the environment.
The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.
Use physical reasoning to complete the following plan in a structured format. Carefully map the required motion in the world to the required motion, forces, and torques at the wrist.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
